docs.title: Welcome to the JellyFAAS docs
docs.text: Integrate seamlessly into your work flow.

docs.title: Behind the scenes
docs.text:
Your function calls do a lot behind the scenes that you don't see!

sequenceDiagram
Client->>+JellyFaas Api: Authourise Api key
JellyFaas Api->>-Client: JWT

Client->>+JellyFaas Api: Lookup function
JellyFaas Api->>+JellyFaas Functions Library: Lookup function 
JellyFaas Functions Library->>-JellyFaas Api: Function requirments and dns 
JellyFaas Api->>-Client: Function requirments and dns 

Client->>+JellyFaas Api: Invoke
JellyFaas Api->>+JellyFaas Cloud Instance: Invoke
    critical Connect to function instance
        JellyFaas Cloud Instance-->Google Cloud Function: connect
        JellyFaas Cloud Instance-->Google Cloud Function: run
        JellyFaas Cloud Instance-->Google Cloud Function: process response 
    end
JellyFaas Cloud Instance->>-JellyFaas Api: Function response
JellyFaas Api->>-Client: Function response

docs.title: Getting Started Guide
docs.text: We've stream lined everything, so you don't have too.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
We support a wide range of languages - find your language to get started with our SDK.

PythonJavaGoC#Node

The JellyFaaS SDK Python package is available on PyPI: 

pip install jellyfaas

Add this maven dependency to your POM.xml file: 

<dependency>
    // placeholder
</dependency>

Use the go get command to install the package: 

go get github.com/Platform48/go_sdk

Using the dotnet cli to add it to your .dotNet project:

dotnet add package JellyfaasSdk

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK simplifies working with the JellyFaaS API. It primarily provides a Client class which handles authentication and functions to simplify creating HTTP requests to the API.

API Credits

The cloud functions used in the examples below will not use your credits. Click here to get an api key.

Below are some quick start examples you can plug and play into.

PythonJavaGoC#Node

Get started with this easy python file.

main.py

from jellyfaas import Client, ClientConfig

# Initialize the client config
config = ClientConfig("<JELLYFAAS_API_KEY>")

# 1. Create Client, 2. lookup JellyFaaS function, 3. pass in query params and body, 4. invoke!
client, response = Client(config).lookup_function("helloworld")
                                 .set_request({"name": "tim"}, {"order": ["ham", "jam", "spam"]})
                                 .invoke()

print(response)
# Output: "Hello, Tim. You ordered 'ham', 'jam', and 'spam'."

More Info - Verbose Example

The above code example demonstrates how the entire JellyFaaS function calling workflow can be condensed down into a succinct one-liner. Of course, you may prefer a more a clear and verbose approach. The following code example demonstrates how you can improve code-clarity by expanding out this process. 

import os
import logging
import jellyfaas

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG) # When enabled, JellyFaaS logs at the DEBUG level

# It is usually recommended to set up your API key as an environment variable.
api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

# Initialize the client config with debug logs enabled
config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key=api_key, debug=True)

# Initialize the client. 
# Once you have an authenticated Client, you can reuse it for multiple lookups/invocations.
client = jellyfaas.Client(config)

# Lookup a function
client.lookup_function("helloworld")

# Set the request query params and JSON body (via a python dictionary)
# Once you've done this once, you can call `invoke()` on the client as many times as you want.
client.set_request(
    {"name": "tim"},                # Set query parameters
    {"order": ["ham", "jam", "spam"]}) # Set request body

# Finally, call the cloud function
_, response = client.invoke()

print(response)
# Output: "Hello, Tim. You ordered 'ham', 'jam', and 'spam'."

Try out this java example using the main, input, and output classes provided.

CodeInput ClassOutput Class

Main.java

package main;

import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonProcessingException;
import testSchemas.IbanOutputTest;
import testSchemas.IbanTest;
import v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasException;
import v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasFormatException;
import v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasHttpException;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasHttpException, IllegalAccessException, JsonProcessingException, JellyFaasFormatException {
        // setting the config object
        String apiKey = System.getenv("API_KEY");
        Config config = new Config();
        config.setApiKey(apiKey);

        //creating the client object
        Client client = new Client(config);
        IbanTest ibanTest = new IbanTest();
        ibanTest.addIban("FR1420041010050500013M02606");

        // invoking the object and putting the output into a new object
        IbanOutputTest output = (IbanOutputTest) client.lookUp("ibanvalidation").setRequest(null, ibanTest).setResponse(IbanOutputTest.class).invoke();
    }
}

Input.java

package main;

import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonProperty;
import v1.jellyfaas.JellyFaasFunctionSchema;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class IbanTest extends JellyFaasFunctionSchema {
    private List<String> ibans;

    public IbanTest(){
        this.ibans = new ArrayList<>();
    }

    public List<String> getIbans() {
        return this.ibans;
    }

    public void setIbans(List<String> ibans) {
        this.ibans = ibans;
    }

    public void addIban(String iban){
        this.ibans.add(iban);
    }
}

Output.java

package main;
import v1.jellyfaas.JellyFaasFunctionSchema;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class IbanOutputTest extends JellyFaasFunctionSchema {
    private String spanId;
    private Data data;

    // Getter and Setter for spanId
    public String getSpanId() {
        return spanId;
    }

    public void setSpanId(String spanId) {
        this.spanId = spanId;
    }

    // Getter and Setter for Data
    public Data getData() {
        return data;
    }

    public void setData(Data data) {
        this.data = data;
    }

    // Inner class Data
    public static class Data {
        private List<String> valid = new ArrayList<>();
        private List<String> invalid = new ArrayList<>();
        private int validCount = 0;
        private int invalidCount = 0;
        private int total = 0;

        // Getters and Setters for valid
        public List<String> getValid() {
            return valid;
        }

        public void setValid(List<String> valid) {
            this.valid = valid;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for invalid
        public List<String> getInvalid() {
            return invalid;
        }

        public void setInvalid(List<String> invalid) {
            this.invalid = invalid;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for validCount
        public int getValidCount() {
            return validCount;
        }

        public void setValidCount(int validCount) {
            this.validCount = validCount;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for invalidCount
        public int getInvalidCount() {
            return invalidCount;
        }

        public void setInvalidCount(int invalidCount) {
            this.invalidCount = invalidCount;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for total
        public int getTotal() {
            return total;
        }

        public void setTotal(int total) {
            this.total = total;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: SDK Guide
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK simplifies working with the JellyFaaS API. It provides a Client class which handles authentication and functions to simplify creating HTTP requests to the API. It also provides additional validation and checks of your requests, to prevent making invalid function calls, which would otherwise consume API credits.

API Credits

The cloud functions used in the examples below will not use your credits. Click here to get an api key.

Here is a walk through using the Hello World function.

docs.title: 1. Creating a Config object
docs.text:
The first step is to create your config object and parse your JellyFaaS api key into it. The config handles keys and authorisation.

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
import os
from jellyfaas import ClientConfig

api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

if api_key is None:
raise ValueError("API key is not set in environment variables")

config = ClientConfig(api_key=api_key, debug=True)

Config config = new Config();
config.setApiKey("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY");

config := JellyConfig{
    ApiKey: "JELLYFAAS_API_KEY",
}

JellyConfig config = new JellyConfig("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY");

docs.title: 2. Creating the Client
docs.text:
After that, you can create the client, and parse the newly created 'config' object into it:

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
from jellyfaas import Client

# initilize config object here 

client = Client(config)

Client client = new Client(config);

c := NewClient(config)

JellyClient client = new JellyClient(config);

docs.title: 3. Looking up a function
docs.text:
To look up a function, you must use the function's short name to find it. Provided all the previous steps are complete, add the following:

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
client.lookup_function("helloworld")

client.lookUp("helloworld");



client.Lookup("helloworld");

docs.title: 4. Setting the request
docs.text:
Once you've called 'lookup' on your client object, you can now set your request. If a function takes no query parameters and/or no input body, the setRequest parameters can be 'nil' respectively. This dependent on the function, so check the functions requirements if you aren't sure.

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
client.set_request(queryParams, requestBody)

client.setRequest(queryParams, requestBody);



client.SetRequest(queryParams, requestBody)

Note

queryParams and requestBody are placeholders for the following steps below

docs.title: 4.1 Setting query parameters
docs.text:
The helloworld function requires two query parameters: firstname and lastname. You can set them as follows:

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
query_params={
    "firstname": "foo",
    "lastname": "bar"
}

Creating query parameters is done by creating a Map<String, String> - where the key value pairs are the query parameter name and its value respectively.

Map<String, String> queryParams = new HashMap<>();
queryParams.put("firstname", "foo");
queryParams.put("lastname", "bar");



var parameters = new Dictionary<string, string>() {
    {"firstname", "foo"},
    {"lastname", "bar"}
};

docs.title: 4.2 Setting the body
docs.text:
The website will contain an autogenerated input object (depending on the language this could be a class, a struct, dict, etc) for you to copy/paste into your project. For this example we are using the HellWorld input and output objects. Populate this struct and parse it in with the following:

PythonJavaGoC#Node

For python, the request body can either be set using a dictionary,

DictionaryClass Instance 
request_body = {
"message": "JellyFaaS is cool",
"rating": 5.0
}

class Review:
    def __init__(message, rating):
        self.message = message
        self.rating = rating

request_body = Review("JellyFaaS is cool", 5.0)

Using the function's autogenerated input class from the website, you can add the following: 

SomeInputClass requestBody = new SomeInputClass();
requestBody.setSomeAttribute("foobar");

Warning

Sometimes the package might be incorrect on the auto-generated classes on the website. The default package for all generated classes is main but you may need to change this.



SomeInputClass requestBody = new SomeInputClass();
requestBody.SetSomeAttribute("foobar");

docs.title: 5. Setting the response
docs.text:
The SDK allows you to automatically map the response JSON to a specified class. This is useful for managing complex responses. The website will contain an autogenerated output object that you can copy/paste into your project. Again this is language dependent so these objects will be different.

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
class MyResponse:
    def __init__(self):
        self.message = None
        self.status = None

client.set_response(MyResponse)

client.setResponse(someOutput.class);

Aforementioned, you must use the autogenerated output class and add this to your project. You don't need an instance of this as invoke will return the same type as the output class.

Warning

setRequest() is not defined in C# SDK. Instead, Invoke() takes a generic type for the auto-generated class. See section 6. Invoke for an example

docs.title: 6. Invoking the function
docs.text:
You are ready to call your function! Simply call invoke() and your function will be called.

PythonJavaGoC#Node 
client, result = (
    jellyfaas.Client(config)
        .lookup_function("helloworld")
        .set_request(query_params=query_params, request_body_instance=request_body)
        .invoke()
)

Info

Python's invoke will either return a new dictionary if set_response was not called, or if set_response was called, invoke will return an object of the class give in set_response.

OutputClass myOutput = (OutputClass) client.lookUp("helloworld").setRequest(params, body).setResponse(someOutput.class).invoke();



SomeOutput output = client.Lookup("joesjokes").SetRequest(params, body).Invoke<SomeOutput>();

Note

Invoke takes a <generic> type, therefore, it's return type is inferred from this. This is why the C# SDK doesn't have the setResponse() method.

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK provides custom exceptions for different error scenarios. Below is a description of each error type and where to expect it to be thrown for each SDK:

PythonJavaGoC#Node

  1. jellyfaas.AuthenticationFailedException

    Thrown when your credentials cannot be verfied during config object creation.

  2. jellyfaas.FunctionLookupException

    Occurs during the function look up stage. This could be due to the function not exisiting

  3. jellyfaas.SetRequestException

    This can be down to the query parameters being incorrect and therefore not lining up with the function's query parameter schema. Or, this can be due to the input body not matching the functions input schema.

  4. jellyfaas.InvocationException

  1. v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasException

    This is a general error that can be thrown during the process of calling out to a function

  2. v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasFormatException

    This error is thrown when there are issues with your request body and request parameters. This is usually due to errors with the schema not matching these inputs

  3. v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasHttpException

    Occurs during any failures with calling out to the function or setting your authorsiation JWT.

  1. Jellyfaas.UnauthorizedException

    This error is thrown when a user attempts to perform an action without the necessary permissions.

  2. Jellyfaas.FunctionNotFoundException

    This error occurs when the specified function does not exist or cannot be found. It may also include a custom message indicating the function name.

  3. Jellyfaas.FunctionNotSelectedException

    This error is raised when no function has been selected for the SDK to use. The SDK requires a function to be specified in order to proceed.

  4. Jellyfaas.EmptyBodyException

    This error is triggered when a function requires a non-empty body, but an empty or missing body is provided in the request.

  5. Jellyfaas.NonSchemaCompliantException

    This error is thrown when an object does not match the required schema, indicating that the input does not conform to the expected format or structure.

  6. Jellyfaas.InvalidSchemaException

    This error occurs when the schema associated with a function is invalid or not correctly defined, preventing the function from executing as expected.

docs.title: Debug mode
docs.text:
If you want a more verbose output from the SDK, you set the SDK to be in debug mode with the following:

PythonJavaGoC#Node

Both ClientConfig and Client classes utilize Python's built-in logging module. Ensure that your application is configured to capture these logs:

import logging

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

This is toggled by calling debug on the client and setting a boolean:

// dubugging enabled
client.debug(true);

// debugging disabled
client.debug(false);



var loggerFactory = LoggerFactory.Create((builder) => builder.AddConsole());
var logger = loggerFactory.CreateLogger("Jellyfaas");

JellyClient client = new JellyClient(new JellyConfig("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY", logger, true));

Note

Other logging librarys can be used and parsed into the config object.

docs.text:
Last updated: Sep 04, 2024 at 14:39

This is the Java v1 reference guide. If you want more information about how to get started with SDKs, click here.

Found a problem? Report it here.

docs.title: Java SDK - Alpha
docs.text: The JellyFaas Java SDK. Here's a quick guide on how to get started with the SDK.

docs.title: Setting the config object
docs.text:
This object handles any keys and tokens that are required throughout the life cycle of the client. The config will generate any jwt tokens and authorisation required at run time. 

Config config = new Config();
config.setApiKey("API-KEY");
...

docs.title: Creating a client
docs.text:
Start by creating a Client, this takes a config object (created above).

Client client = new Client(config);

docs.title: Function Lookup
docs.text:
Each function has its own unique shortname - these are used to look up functions. This is done by calling .lookUp("shortname"). 

client.lookUp("shortname");

docs.title: Setting the request parameters
docs.text: This is the most error-prone function as this validates an input body against the functions schema ,which is fetched when .lookUp("shortname") is called. To set the request, you must call .setRequest(Map<String, String>, Object) on the client object.

docs.title: Query Parameters
docs.text: These are set using a Map<String, String> for the key value pairs for the query params the function takes. These are validated before the call is made to the function.

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text: All request body's and response body's inherit JellyFaasFunctionSchema. Each request and response class is unique to each function. A populated request schema must be parsed into this function.

docs.title: Setting the Response Body
docs.text: A response object must be provided, which lets the response be accessible. This can either be a Class< ? > or it can be an instance of an object. If a Class< ? > is provided, the invoke() function will return a instance of that class. If an instance is provided, the data will be marshalled into this instance provided the schema is correct.

docs.title: Invoking
docs.text: This is the last method to make a request out to the function provided the previous methods have been called. If a Class< ? > is provided, the invoke() function will return a instance of that class. If an instance is provided, the data will be marshalled into this instance provided the schema is correct.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example with parsing the OutputClass class. 

// creating a config object
Config config = new Config();
config.setApiKey("API-KEY");

// setting the client
Client client = new Client(config);

// creating an input object
InputClass input = new InputClass();
inputClass.setSomeAttribute("foobar");

// invoking the function with the OutputClass.class as the response object
OutputClass output = (OutputClass) client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, input).setResponse(OutputClass.class).invoke();

docs.title: public class Client
docs.text:
Warning

This project is under active development!

Found a problem? Report it here.

Client required to make calls out to JellyFaaS functions. Supports method chaining for easy callouts.

docs.title: public Client(Config config) throws JellyFaasException
docs.text:
public Client(Config config) throws JellyFaasException

Client object is used to make calls to the functions hosted in JellyFaas.

param

  • config JellyFaas Config object

throws

  • JellyFaasException if the config object is null

docs.title: public Client setResponse(Object output)
docs.text:
public Client setResponse(Object output)

Sets the object the response will be marshalled into. This can be a Class<?> or an instance of an object : Client client = new Client("key"); client.setResponse(OutputObject.class); // or OutputObject outputObj = new OutputObject(); client.setResponse(outputObj)

param

  • output the class for the output object to be

return

  • Current Client

docs.title:
public Client setRequest(Map queryParams, Object requestBody) throws JellyFaasException, JsonProcessingException, JellyFaasFormatException 

public Client setRequest(Map<String, String> queryParams, Object requestBody) throws JellyFaasException, JsonProcessingException, JellyFaasFormatException

Sets the body and query parameters for a request. This method will validate the body against the function's schema.

param

  • queryParams a string to string mapping of the query parameters

  • requestBody an object for the input body

return

  • Current Client

throws

  • JellyFaasException if the queryParams are invalid or the requestBody is invalid

  • JsonProcessingException when the input schema cannot be validated

  • JellyFaasFormatException when the provided input class has missing types or the incorrect types against the json schema

public Client lookUp(String shortName) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasHttpException 

public Client lookUp(String shortName) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasHttpException

Determines which function to call to via the given short name.

param

  • shortName the shortname assigned to a function. E.g., 'examplefunc'

return

  • Current Client

throws

  • JellyFaasException when there as issue sending the http request to the JellyFaas auth service

  • JellyFaasHttpException when the user supplies invalid credentials, or there is an issue with the auth service

public Object invoke() throws JellyFaasHttpException, JellyFaasException 

public Object invoke() throws JellyFaasHttpException, JellyFaasException

Method calls a JellyFaas function with the given parameters. : Client client = new Client("key"); Output output = client.setAuth().lookUp("functionshortname").setRequest(queryParams, body).setResponse(Output.class).invoke();

return

  • a new object if #setResponse(Object) is a Class<?>

throws

  • JellyFaasHttpException when a HTTP error occurs calling out to the service

  • JellyFaasException if the response object is null or if the config object is null

protected byte[] getResponse() 

protected byte[] getResponse()

Returns the response from the called from #invoke().

return

  • HttpResponse object.

public String toString() throws NullPointerException 

public String toString() throws NullPointerException

this is useful for parsing the response as JSON

return

  • the response body as a string

public Client debug(boolean flag) 

public Client debug(boolean flag)

Will print out debug lines if set to true.

param

  • flag determines if debug mode will be used.

return

  • Current Client

public int getStatusCode() 

public int getStatusCode()

Returns the status code of the function call

return

  • the status code of response

private void validateQueryParams(Map params) throws JellyFaasException 

private void validateQueryParams(Map<String, String> params) throws JellyFaasException

Validates the query params against the functions' schema.

param

  • params mapping of key value pairs for the query params

throws

  • JellyFaasException when there's a required parameter

private void validateJSONSchema(JSONObject schema, JSONObject body) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasFormatException 

private void validateJSONSchema(JSONObject schema, JSONObject body) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasFormatException

Recursive function to compare against the body against the schema to see if the body has got any extra information and compare the schema against the body to see if the body is missing information.

param

  • body input json body

  • schema input schema for the body

throws

  • JellyFaasException when there is an issue with the body matching the json schema

  • JellyFaasFormatException when the provided input class has missing types or the incorrect types against the json schema

apiNote

  • this is only used to check json schemas

private void validateSchema(byte[] body, JSONObject schema) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasFormatException 

private void validateSchema(byte[] body, JSONObject schema) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasFormatException

Validates the request body.

throws

  • JellyFaasException if there is an incompatible schema, an incompatible json body, or when the body

  • JellyFaasFormatException when the provided input class has missing types or the incorrect types against the json schema doesn't match the schema

apiNote

  • this only works for json body data.

private HttpResponse doCall(String url, String method, Map headers, HttpRequest.BodyPublisher requestBody) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasHttpException

Handles calling out to the auth service with a given url, using the api-key.

This project is under active development!

The config object handles the authentication for a user wanting to use JellyFaaS. Config object uses a JellyFaaS api key to generate a valid JWT when making a call.

docs.title: JellyFAAS Python SDK
docs.text: This Python module provides a client for interacting with the JellyFAAS API. The client supports authentication, function lookup, setting request parameters, invoking functions, and handling responses with optional response class transformation.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.12+ (Note: Need to test earlier versions?)
  • requests library

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Ensure you have the requests library installed. If not, you can install it using pip:

pip install requests

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text: It is recommended to set your API key as an environment variable.

docs.title: Initialization
docs.text:
Create an instance of the ClientConfig class with your API key:

  • Parameters:
    • api_key (str): Your JellyFAAS API key.
    • debug (bool): Optional. Enables debug logging if set to True.
  • Returns:
    • The ClientConfig instance.
config = ClientConfig(api_key="your_api_key", debug=True)

The ClientConfig class handles the authentication with the JellyFAAS API and manages the API key and authentication token.

docs.title: Initialization
docs.text:
Create an instance of the Client class using the ClientConfig object:

  • Parameters:
    • config (ClientConfig): The ClientConfig instance.
  • Returns:
    • The Client instance.
client = Client(config=config)

docs.title: lookup_function(function_id)
docs.text:
Look up a function by its ID (shortname).

  • Parameters:
    • function_id (str): The ID (shortname) of the function to look up.
  • Returns:
    • The Client instance.

Example:

client.lookup_function("FUNCTION_ID")

docs.title: set_request(query_params={}, request_body_instance=None)
docs.text:
Set the request parameters and body.

  • Parameters:
    • query_params (dict): Query parameters for the request.
    • request_body_instance (dict or object): JSON body for the request. Can be a dictionary or an instance of a class with attributes.
  • Returns:
    • The Client instance.

Example:

client.set_request(query_params={"param1": "value1"}, request_body_instance={"key": "value"})

docs.title: invoke()
docs.text:
Invoke the function with the set parameters and body.

  • Returns:
    • A tuple of the Client instance and the response JSON if successful, otherwise raises an exception.

Example:

client, result = client.invoke()

docs.title: set_response(type)
docs.text:
Set the response type for automatic transformation of the response JSON into an instance of a specified class.

  • Parameters:
    • type (class): The class type to transform the response JSON into.
  • Returns:
    • The Client instance.

Example:

client.set_response(MyResponseClass)

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text: Both ClientConfig and Client classes use Python's built-in logging module to provide debug and error logs. Ensure you configure the logging level appropriately in your application.

docs.title: Complete Example Usage:
docs.text:
import os
import jellyfaas

# Retrieve the API key from environment variable
api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

if api_key is None:
    raise ValueError("API key is not set in environment variables")

# Define a response class (optional)
class MyResponse:
    def __init__(self):
        self.key = None
        self.value = None

# Create a JellyFAAS config and client, then invoke a function
config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key=api_key, debug=True)
client, result = (
    jellyfaas.Client(config)
    .lookup_function("joesjokes")
    .set_request(query_params={"param1": "value1"}, request_body_instance={"key": "value"})
    .set_response(MyResponse)
    .invoke()
)

print(result)

docs.title: Handling Exceptions
docs.text:
The SDK raises custom exceptions for various error conditions:

  • AuthenticationFailedException: Raised when authentication fails.
  • FunctionLookupException: Raised when function lookup fails.
  • SetRequestException: Raised when setting the request parameters or body fails.
  • InvocationException: Raised when invocation of the function fails.

These all inherit from a base JellyFaasException type, which you can optionally use to catch all exceptions from the SDK.

Example:

import jellyfaas
import os

api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

try:
    config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key=api_key)
    client, result = (
        jellyfaas.Client(config)
        .lookup_function("joesjokes")
        .set_request(query_params={"param1": "value1"}, request_body_instance={"key": "value"})
        .invoke()
    )
    print(result)
except jellyfaas.AuthenticationFailedException as e:
    print(f"Authentication failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.FunctionLookupException as e:
    print(f"Function lookup failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.SetRequestException as e:
    print(f"Setting request failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.InvocationException as e:
    print(f"Function invocation failed: {e}")

docs.title: Additional Information
docs.text:
The client supports validation of request bodies against input schemas if provided in the function requirements. It also includes debug logging to help trace the internal state and steps of computation, aiding in debugging and development.

Ensure you have configured logging in your application to capture debug logs:

import logging

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

docs.title: class Client
docs.text:
Warning

This project is under active development!

Found a problem? Report it here.

A client for interacting with the JellyFAAS API. It is not recommended to access attributes of this class directly; instead, use "public" class functions as per the documentation.

attribute

  • _api_key (str) The API key used for authentication.

  • _token (str) The authentication token.

  • _token_expiry (str) The expiration time for the token.

  • _version (str) The version of the function to lookup.

  • _size (str) The size of the function to lookup.

  • _response (Any) The response from the invoked function.

  • _response_type (Any) The type of the response for transformation.
